document.docTitle: Revision of the Echiniscus bigranulatus group with a description of a new species Echiniscus madonnae (Tardigrada: Heterotardigrada: Echiniscidae) from South America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Echiniscus bigranulatus group with a description of a new species Echiniscus madonnae (Tardigrada: Heterotardigrada: Echiniscidae) from South America

paragraph.emphasis:
Revision of the
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group with a description of a new species
Echiniscus madonnae
(Tardigrada:

subSection.paragraph:
ŁUKASZ MICHALCZYK 1 * & ŁUKASZ KACZMAREK 2
1
Institute of Environmental Sciences, Jagiellonian University, Gronostajowa 7, 30­ 387 Kraków, Poland . E­mail: agnostic@poczta.fm

paragraph.emphasis: *Present address: Centre for Ecology, Evolution and Conservation, School of Biological Sciences, University of East Anglia , Norwich NR 4 7 TJ, UK

subSection.paragraph:
2
Department of Animal Taxonomy and Ecology, A. Mickiewicz University, Umultowska 89, 61­ 614 Pozna
Ĥ,
Poland E­mail: kacztar@poczta.fm

A new species,
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
, is described from moss samples collected in Peru . So far it is the only species within the
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group that does not have true pores in the dorsal plate cuticle. This paper contains also a redescription of
Echiniscus bigranulatus Richters
and updated descriptions of
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis Nickel et al.
and
Echiniscus ranzii Ramazzotti. In
this paper we also provide a SEM analysis of the dorsal plate cuticle structure.

Key words: Tardigrada,
Echiniscus bigranulatus
,
E. madonnae
sp. nov.
,
E. ollantaytamboensis
,
E. ranzii
, new species , redescription, South America

The number of described tardigrade species is nearing one thousand (
Guidetti & Bertolani 2005
). Around 15 % of all known species belong to the genus
Echiniscus Schultze
which makes it currently the most species rich genus within the phylum.

In this paper we provide a redescription of
Echiniscus bigranulatus
Richters, 1908
, updated descriptions on
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
Nickel et al. , 2001
and
Echiniscus ranzii
Ramazzotti, 1964
and a description of a new species
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
We also provide some notes on the cuticular structure of the dorsal plate.

We have examined type material of
E. madonnae
sp. nov.
,
E. ollantaytamboensis
and
E. ranzii
and neotype material of
E. bigranulatus
(detailed information on the examined specimens is provided in sections concerning the particular species). All species have been observed in Light Microscopes (LM): Phase Contrast Microscope ( PCM ) and Nomarski Differential Interference Contrast Microscope (DIC). All species except for
E. ranzii
have been analysed using Scanning Electron Microscope ( SEM ). After the first SEM session some specimens were delicately torn using a fine needle and then coated with platinum once again. This technique enabled a three dimensional observation of cuticle internal structure. Schemes of the cuticle sections were based on SEM photomicrographs made using this technique.

All measurements are given in micrometers [µm]. Structures were measured only if they were undamaged and their orientation was suitable. Body length was measured from the anterior margin to the end of the body, excluding the hind legs. Only external claws were measured.
Microphotographs were made using and SEM , PCM and DIC.
Species descriptions are in alphabetical order.

subSubSection.paragraph:
‘Sponge layer’ absent, large pillars present (
Figs. 11 –12
, 72 ). Undeveloped pillars in shape of blunt projections visible under pores. Cuticle visible in PCM : pores visible as bright fields, cuticular pillars appear as dark dots. Pores on the same focus level as pillars (
Figs. 5–6
). Both pores and cuticular pillars very well focusable. Ventral cuticle with very fine, dense and regular granulation.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4.
Echiniscus bigranulatus
— habitus (2 — neotype, the rest of the specimens is from Costa Rica); 1, dorso­lateral view (DIC), 2, dorso lateral view (PCM, neotype), 3, lateral view (SEM), 4, dorsal view (SEM).

FIGURES 5–8.
Echiniscus bigranulatus
— dorsal plate cuticle; 5, DIC, 6, PCM, 7–8, SEM; 5 and 6 show the same fragment of cuticle.

FIGURES 9–12.
Echiniscus bigranulatus
— cuticle; 9, anterior plates (SEM), 10, posterior plates (SEM), 11–12, structure of dorsal plate cuticle (SEM) (see also Fig. 72).

FIGURES 13–16.
Echiniscus bigranulatus
. 13–14, second median plate (PCM and SEM, respectively), 15–16, third median plate (PCM and SEM, respectively). Not scaled.

FIGURES 17–20.
Echiniscus bigranulatus
. 17, papilla and dentate collar on the IV pair of legs (PCM), 18, dentate collar and claws of the IV pair of legs (PCM), 19, papilla, dentate collar and claws on the IV pair of legs (SEM), 20, claws on the III pair of legs (SEM).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Results of simple statistical analysis of measurements of selected morphological structures for
7 specimens
from Costa Rica are given in
Table 1
. No males, juveniles, larvae and eggs were found.

All of the specimens found across South and Central America are very similar, therefore we have assumed that the intraspecific variability in
E. bigranulatus
is low.

According to the original description claws are devoid of the spurs, while all specimens that we have examined had spurs on internal claws of all legs. We think that spurs could have been overlooked, due to a relatively low angle in which they grow out of the claw. Sometimes, when claws are very closely arranged to each other, spurs are difficult to identify.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of adults of
Echiniscus bigranulatus Richters, 1908
from Costa Rica mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N — number of specimens/structures measured).

subSubSection.paragraph: Known from South and Central America . Records of this species in Africa need to be reconfirmed, however it seems to be very likely that the South African specimens belong to a different species.

Neotype and
3 specimens
from Costa Rica are preserved at the Natural Sciences Collection, Faculty of Biology, A. Mickiewicz University, Umultowska 89, 61– 614 Poznań, Poland ;
3 specimens
from Costa Rica are preserved in the collection of Ł. Michalczyk.

The name ‘
bigranulatus
’ was given by Ferdinand Richters as he probably thought that dorsal plates are covered with ‘double granulation’.

For comparisons with other species of the
bigranulatus
group see
Tables 7–8
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 21–24.
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
— habitus (21–22 holotype, 23–24 paratype); 21, dorso­lateral view (DIC), 22, dorso­lateral view (PCM), 23, lateral view (SEM), 24, dorsal view (SEM); 21 and 22 show the same specimen, 23 and 24 show the same specimen.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Results of simple statistical analysis of measurements of selected morphological structures for 24 randomly chosen adult specimens are given in
Table 2
and for all found juvenile specimens in
Table 3
. No males, larvae and eggs were found.

Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.

FIGURES 31–34.
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.

FIGURES 35–38.
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
35–36, second median plate (DIC and SEM, respectively), 37–38, weakly developed third median plate (DIC and SEM, respectively). Not scaled.

subSubSection.paragraph: Known only from the type locality.

TABLE 2. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of adults of
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N — number of specimens/structures measured).

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype and 9 paratypes are preserved at the Natural Sciences Collection, Faculty of Biology, A. Mickiewicz University, Umultowska 89, 61– 614 Poznań, Poland ; 20 paratypes are preserved in the collection of Ł. Michalczyk.
We take great pleasure in dedicating this species to one of the most significant artists of our times, Madonna Louise Veronica Ritchie.

For comparisons with other species of the
bigranulatus
group see
Tables 7–8
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 3. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of juveniles of
Echiniscus madonnae
sp. nov.
mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N — number of specimens/structures measured).

heading.emphasis:
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
Nickel, Miller & Marley, 2001
(
Figs. 43 –68
, 73 )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Two paratypes (
1 adult
and
1 juvenile
), from Ollantaytambo, Peru , South America ; 42 Description

tr.th: specimens found in a lichen sample in

subSubSection.paragraph:
Results of simple statistical analysis of measurements of selected morphological structures for 13 randomly chosen adult specimens are given in
Table 4
, for all found juvenile specimens in
Table 5
, and for all found larvae in
Table 6
. One exuvium with three round eggs was found (eggs ca. 100.0 in diameter).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 43–46.
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
— habitus (specimens from Puno, Peru); 43, dorso­lateral view (DIC), 44, dorso­lateral view (PCM), 45, lateral view (SEM), 46, dorsal view (SEM); 45 and 46 show the same specimen.

FIGURES 47–52.
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
— dorsal plate cuticle; 47, surface with pores (PCM), 48, pillars that appear when focusing down through the cuticle (PCM), 49, surface with pores (DIC), 50, pillars that appear when focusing down through the cuticle (DIC), 51, surface with pores, pseudopores and granules in the anterior part of one of the first paired plates (note strips of cuticle connecting granules and how granulated area with pseudopores smoothly becomes a plate with true pores), 52, surface with pores (SEM); 47 and 48 show the same fragment of cuticle, 49 and 50 show the same fragment of cuticle.

FIGURES 53–54.
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
— structure of dorsal plate cuticle (SEM) (see also Fig. 73).

FIGURES 55–60.
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
. 55, second median plate in a younger animal (DIC), 56–57, second median plate in an older animal (DIC and SEM, respectively), 58, weakly developed third median plate in a younger animal (DIC), 59–60, better developed third median plate in an older animal (DIC and SEM, respectively). Not scaled.

subSubSection.paragraph: The authors of the original description state also yellow colour of the body and that the body length varies between 180.0 and 275.0. In the population from Puno (including larvae) body length extremes are 147.3 and 467.4 . and colour was more reddish. These differences are probably due to different environmental conditions in which two population have lived.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 61–68.
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
. 61–64, dentate collar on the IV pair of legs (DIC) (61 and 62 come from the same specimen, 63 and 64 come from the same specimen), 65, dentate collar sculpture (SEM), 66–67, claws of the IV pair of legs (DIC and PCM, respectively), 68, claws of the III pair of legs (SEM).

TABLE 4. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of adults of
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N — number of specimens/structures measured). Specimens from population found in Peru.

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype and 9 paratypes are preserved at the Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia, PA, USA ; 2 paratypes are preserved in the collection of Ł. Michalczyk.
The species was named in honour of the ancient Inca ‘Temple of the Sun’, Ollantaytambo, Peru , near where it was found.

For comparisons with other species of the
bigranulatus
group see
Tables 7–8
.
Syntype , slide no. CT 12742 , mounted in Faure’s medium, from Cerro del Pajonal, Chile , South America (The Ramazzotti & Maucci Collection, Museum of Verona, Italy ).

Based mainly on the data from
Ramazzotti & Maucci ( 1983 )
. Body length 124.0 to 320.0, including larvae ( syntype : 171.0) (
Fig. 69
). Body red. Red eyes visible in living specimens only. Internal/external cirrus ratio ca. 0.33–0.50 . Apart from head cirri and cirrus A, no other appendices present. Cirrus A 128.0–200.0 long ( syntype : 87.4 ), ending in a point. Cirrus A/body ratio 0.50–0.90 , mean = 0.66 ± 0.03 ( syntype : 0.51 ).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 5. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of juveniles of
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N —

subSubSection.paragraph: number of specimens/structures measured). Specimens from population found in Peru .

Dorsal (plate) cuticle probably with true pores and with true granulation. Granules (true granulation, on cuticle surface) present on stripes in anterior portions of paired plates and in anterior part of second median plate. Granules variable in size ( 0.5 –1.0 in diameter). Cuticle appearance in PCM : pores visible as bright, cuticular pillars appear as dark dots. Pores and cuticular pillars very well focusable, at same level.

All plates well developed. Head and scapular plates not faceted. Third median plate present and well developed, in smaller specimens developed anteriorly. Terminal plate faceted. Notches in syntype 14.3 long.

Since we were able to examine only one syntype and the original description was written forty years ago, the description of this species is relatively poor in comparison to other species within the
bigranulatus
group. However a set of characters makes this species very easily recognisable among other known members of the group ( e.g. , a very high Cirrus A /body ratio and the presence of spurs on external claws).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 6. Lengths [in µm] and length ratios of selected morphological structures of larvae of
Echiniscus ollantaytamboensis
mounted in Hoyer’s medium (MIN and MAX refer to the smallest and the largest structure found among all measured specimens; SD — Standard Deviation, N — number of specimens/structures measured). Specimens from population found in Peru.

TABLE 7. Statistical comparisons of mean lengths of selected morphological structures and their length ratios between adults of all known species within the
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group. The p values for the independent sample t test are provided and statistically significant differences are marked in bold (p<0.050). Arrows indicate whether the first species mean is higher or lower in a particular comparison (10 specimens of
E. bigranulatus
, 24 specimens of
E. madonnae
sp. nov .
and 13 specimens of
E. ollantaytamboensis
were compared).

subSubSection.paragraph: Known only from the type locality.
Type specimens are preserved at the Museum of Verona, Italy .
The species was named after Professor Silvio Ranzii .

For comparisons with other species of the
bigranulatus
group see
Tables 7–8
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 8. Comparisons of characters, mean lengths of selected morphological structures and their length ratios between adults of all known species within the
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group (* — ranges, since means were not provided in the original description).

subSubSection.paragraph:
CHARACTER
E. bigranulatus E. madonnae
sp. nov.
E.ollantaytamboensis E. ranzii

Richters, 1908
( type population)
Miller et al., 2001
Ramazzotti, 1964
( neotype (from Puno, Peru ) (original population) description and syntype )

tr.td: True pores, narrow sponge layer and pillars

Not examined, probably like in
E. bigranulatus

tr.th: Anterior portion of second median plate
tr.td: The same as the rest of dorsal plates, but with smaller pores
Covered with granules or sometimes with sculpture similar to the posterior portion
Absent, anteriorly developed in larger specimens
Present, anteriorly developed in small specimens, well developed in large specimens
Fine granulation (pillars) and very faint shallow pseudopores
Same as on dorsal plates, but with more shallow pseudopores
Fine granulation (pillars) and very faint shallow and small pseudopores
On internal claws of all legs
On internal claws of all legs
On internal claws of all legs
On internal claws of all legs, on the fourth pair of legs also on external claws, often double
South and Central America (African records need to be confirmed)
Known only from terra typica ­ Peru
Known only from terra typica — Cerro del Pajonal (Chile)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 69–71.
Echiniscus ranzii
. 69, habitus (dorsal view), 70, external claws of the IV pair of legs, 71, internal claws of the IV pair of legs; 70–71 not scaled (from Ramazzotti & Maucci (1983), modified).

FIGURES 72–74. Structure of dorsal plate cuticle in three species of the
bigranulatus
group (semischematic section based on SEM observations); 72,
E. bigranulatus
(see also Figs. 11–12), 73,
E. ollantaytamboensis
(see also Figs. 53–54), 74,
E. madonnae
sp. nov.
(see also Figs. 31–32); abbreviations: bc — body cavity, cs — cuticle surface, pi — pillar, po — pore, pp — pseudopore, sl — ‘sponge’ layer, up — undeveloped pillar. Not scaled.

subSection.paragraph:
The
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group can be characterised as follows: terrestrial species with ‘double granulation’ on most of the dorsal plates, besides head appendages and lateral cirri A lacking any other appendages, yellow­red body colour, inhabiting South and Central America . SEM observations concluded that the term ‘double granulation’ is not appropriate to describe the sculpture of known species within the group, since the characteristic appearance of the cuticle in LM is caused by the co­presence of pores (or pseudopores) and cuticular pillars (see
Figs. 72–74
).

heading.emphasis:
The Light Microscope key to the adults of the
Echiniscus bigranulatus
group

paragraph.keyLead:
­ Cirrus A /body length ratio equal or greater than 0.45 , external claws of the IV pair of legs with spurs
................................................................................................... E. ranzii

2 . Pseudopores on the dorsal plates present (unfocusable in the Light Microscope), true pores absent
................................................................................. E. madonnae
sp. nov.
­ True pores on the dorsal plates present (focusable in the Light Microscope) .............. 3

3 . Third median plate always present and fully developed, anterior portion of the second median plate covered with pores, cuticle without granulation
............... E. bigranulatus

­ Third median plate absent in smaller specimens and developed in large ones, anterior portion of the second median plate covered with granules and sometimes also with pores, granules always present between head and first median plate .............................
...................................................................................................... E. ollantaytamboensis

subSection.paragraph:
The authors want to thank Mr Anibal Canchaya and Mr Krzysztof Kaczmarek who collected the environmental samples. We are also grateful to Professor Reinhardt Møbjerg Kristensen ( Denmark ) and Professor Giovanni Pilato ( Italy ) for providing specimens of
E. bigranulatus , Dr. Roberto Guidetti
( Italy ) for providing a syntype of
E. ranzii
and Dr. William Randy Miller ( USA ) and Mr. Nigel Marley ( England ) for providing paratypes of
E. ollantaytamboensis
.

This research was partially supported by a grant to the first author from the European Commission’s programme ‘Transnational Access to Major Research Infrastructures’ to COBICE (Copenhagen Biosystematics Centre) and by the Instituto Nacional de Biodiversidad ( INBio ) and the Ministry of Environment and Energy ( MINAE ) with funds from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) through the World Bank, project ALAS with funds from National Science Foundation­grant DEB­0072702 to the second author.
